generalfeedback.text: The psi angle works together with the phi angle to create the characteristic α-helix shape. In PyMOL, you can measure these angles using the measurement wizard and selecting four consecutive atoms in the protein backbone.

questiontext.text: In the exercise analyzing secondary structure elements, how are loops colored when using the secondary structure coloring scheme?

generalfeedback.text: PyMOL uses different colors to distinguish between secondary structure elements (α-helices, β-sheets, and loops). This helps visualize the organization of the protein structure.

feedback.text: Blue is typically used for β-sheets in this coloring scheme, not loops.
Firebrick (red) is used for α-helices in this coloring scheme, not loops.
Correct! In this coloring scheme, loops are colored white to distinguish them from the more ordered secondary structure elements (α-helices and β-sheets).
Yellow is not used for any secondary structure elements in this basic coloring scheme.

questiontext.text: When analyzing β-sheets in PyMOL, which representation is most useful for examining hydrogen bonds between strands?

generalfeedback.text: Different molecular representations in PyMOL serve different purposes. Some are better for overall structure visualization, while others are more suitable for detailed analysis of specific interactions.

feedback.text: While cartoon representation is good for overall secondary structure visualization, it doesn't show the atomic details needed to examine hydrogen bonds.
Surface representation shows the molecular surface but hides the atomic details needed to analyze hydrogen bonds.
Correct! Stick representation shows the atomic positions and bonding clearly, making it ideal for analyzing hydrogen bonds between β-strands.
Sphere representation can be too crowded and doesn't clearly show the bonding patterns needed for hydrogen bond analysis.
